items.question: What is the hypostatic union?
items.answer: The hypostatic union is the theological concept that Jesus Christ is both fully divine and fully human in one person.

items.question: Define the term 'incarnation' in Christian theology.
items.answer: Incarnation refers to the belief that God became flesh in the person of Jesus Christ.

items.question: What did Chalcedon (451 AD) declare about Jesus?
items.answer: The Council of Chalcedon declared that Jesus is one person with two natures, fully divine and fully human, without confusion or division.

items.question: What is the significance of the title 'Son of God' for Jesus?
items.answer: The title 'Son of God' affirms Jesus' divine nature and his unique relationship with God the Father.

items.question: Define 'kenosis' in relation to Jesus.
items.answer: Kenosis refers to the 'self-emptying' of Jesus' own will to become human and accept human limitations, as described in Philippians 2:7.

items.question: What did the Council of Nicaea (325 AD) affirm about Jesus?
items.answer: The Council of Nicaea affirmed the deity of Christ, declaring him to be 'of the same substance' (homoousios) as God the Father.

items.question: What is meant by Jesus' dual nature?
items.answer: Jesus' dual nature refers to him being both fully divine and fully human, an essential belief in Christian theology.

items.question: What did Athanasius argue about Jesus' nature?
items.answer: Athanasius argued that Jesus must be fully divine to offer salvation, as only God can save humanity.

items.question: What is the significance of the title 'Son of Man'?
items.answer: The title 'Son of Man' emphasizes Jesus' humanity and his role as the representative of humanity, as well as a messianic figure.

items.question: Define 'Docetism' in early Christian heresies.
items.answer: Docetism is the belief that Jesus only appeared to be human and that his physical body was an illusion.

items.question: What did Nestorius argue about Jesus' nature?
items.answer: Nestorius argued for a separation between Jesus' divine and human natures, suggesting they were two distinct persons.

items.question: What is the theological importance of Jesus' resurrection?
items.answer: Jesus' resurrection is central to Christian belief, affirming his divine nature and victory over sin and death.

items.question: How does the hypostatic union apply to the story of Jesus calming the storm?
items.answer: The hypostatic union shows Jesus' divine power in calming the storm, while his human experience is shown in his presence with the disciples.

items.question: Apply kenosis to the scenario of Jesus' temptation in the desert.
items.answer: Kenosis is demonstrated as Jesus willingly faces human temptation, relying on divine will rather than his own power to overcome it.

items.question: How does the title 'Son of Man' apply to Jesus' crucifixion?
items.answer: The title 'Son of Man' applies as Jesus represents humanity in suffering and sacrifice, fulfilling his messianic role through the crucifixion.

items.question: Apply the concept of incarnation to Jesus' birth narrative.
items.answer: The incarnation is evident in Jesus' birth, where divine nature enters the world in human form, fulfilling prophecies of a savior born to a virgin.

items.question: Give one strength of the hypostatic union doctrine.
items.answer: A strength is that it provides a coherent explanation of how Jesus can be both fully divine and fully human, preserving core Christian beliefs.

items.question: Give one limitation of Nestorius' view on Jesus' nature.
items.answer: A limitation is that it risks dividing Jesus' personhood, undermining the unity of divine and human natures essential for salvation.

items.question: Evaluate the methodology of the Council of Chalcedon (451 AD).
items.answer: The methodology was authoritative and ecclesiastical, relying on theological debate and consensus among church leaders to define doctrine.

items.question: Give one critique of Docetism.
items.answer: Docetism is critiqued for denying Jesus' true humanity, which is essential for the belief in his genuine experience of human suffering and redemption.
